bestBHT.bht: Those who resist the civil power resist the ordinance of God and shall receive punishment from Him. This refers to resisting the authority that God has established, not magistrates being above the laws. We must be cautious not to oppose God's providence in this way, for those who contend with Him in this manner will not go unpunished.

Henry Alford: 2.] shall receive to themselves condemnation, viz. punishment from God, through His minister, the civil power.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Whosoever therefore resisteth the power...resisteth the ordinance of God."
They that resist shall receive to themselves damnation.
That is, not from the magistrate, but from God, whose authority in the magistrate's is resisted.
Albert Barnes: It is implied, however, that those laws shall not be such as to violate the rights of conscience, or oppose the laws of God.
This means clearly that we are to regard 'government' as instituted by God, and as agreeable to his will.

The word 'damnation' we apply now exclusively to the punishment of hell; to future torments. But this is not necessarily the meaning of the word which is used here... It often simply denotes 'punishment.'
Marvin Vincent: He that resisteth [ο αντιτασσομενος] . Lit., setteth himself in array against.
Ordinance [διαταγη] . From tassw to put in place, which appears in the first resisteth. He setteth himself against that which is divinely set.
John Calvin: As no one can resist God but to his own ruin, he threatens, that they shall not be unpunished who in this respect oppose the providence of God.
Let us then beware, lest we incur this denunciation.
He teaches us in general what end awaits those who contend with God.
Philip Schaff: He who resisteth (or, ‘setteth himself against’) the authority, that particular existing authority, to which he should submit himself.
They that withstand shall receive to themselves judgment, or, ‘condemnation.’ The former is more literal, but the latter sense is evidently implied.
'Paul reproduces here in a certain sense, but in another form, the saying of Jesus (Matthew 26:52): “All they that take the sword shall perish with the sword.”‘ (Godet)
Archibald T. Robertson: He that resisteth (ο αντιτασσομενος). Present middle articular participle of αντιτασσω, old verb to range in battle against.
Withstandeth (ανθεστηκεν). Perfect active indicative of ανθιστημ and intransitive, 'has taken his stand against.'
John Gill: Whosoever therefore resisteth the power...resisteth the ordinance of God."

This is not to be understood, as if magistrates were above the laws...but the apostle is speaking of resisting magistrates in the right discharge of their office, and in the exercise of legal power and authority.
They that resist them...shall receive to themselves damnation; that is, punishment; either temporal...or eternal punishment.
John Wesley: Whosoever resisteth the power — In any other manner than the laws of the community direct.
Shall receive condemnation — Not only from the magistrate, but from God also.

bhtAttempts.bht: Those who resist the civil power are actually resisting the ordinance of God, and as a result, they shall receive punishment from God. When we resist the authority that God has established, we are setting ourselves against His divine order. This is not referring to magistrates being above the laws, but rather to resisting their authority in the proper discharge of their duties. Therefore, we should be cautious not to oppose God's providence in this way, for those who contend with Him in this manner will not go unpunished.

Those who resist the civil power resist the ordinance of God and shall receive punishment from Him. This refers to resisting the authority that God has established, not magistrates being above the laws. We must be cautious not to oppose God's providence in this way, for those who contend with Him in this manner will not go unpunished.

Those who resist the governing authorities set themselves against the divine order established by God. To resist is not just to oppose the civil power, but to resist God's authority itself. Such resistance brings condemnation, punishment that is not only from the magistrate, but also from God. Therefore, we should be cautious not to oppose God's providence, for those who contend with Him will incur their appointed end of punishment. Let us submit to the laws of the community and the exercise of rightful authority, mindful that resistance leads to both temporal and eternal consequences.

To resist the governing authorities is to oppose the divine order established by God; it is a defiance of His ordained structure. In doing so, one brings upon themselves condemnation and punishment not only from human rulers, but also from God. Therefore, it is crucial to be cautious of resisting God's providence, for those who contend with Him will face their destined end of punishment. Submission to the laws and rightful authority is vital, as resistance leads to both temporal and eternal consequences.

Those who resist the governing authorities set themselves against the divine order established by God. To resist is to withstand the power that has been divinely ordained. This resistance brings not only condemnation but also punishment, both temporal and eternal. Therefore, it is crucial to submit to the authority and laws of the community, recognizing that resistance leads to legal and spiritual consequences. In opposing God's providence, one faces the inevitable end of punishment.
